title.value: Effectiveness of regional diffusion MRI measures in distinguishing multiple sclerosis abnormalities within the cervical spinal cord
title.justification: This is the title of the paper as provided in the text.
title.quote: Effectiveness of regional diffusion MRI measures in distinguishing multiple sclerosis abnormalities within the cervical spinal cord

extractions.description: This study explores the effectiveness of diffusion MRI, specifically using metrics from diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) and the Ball-and-Stick model, in identifying and distinguishing multiple sclerosis (MS) lesions within the cervical spinal cord. The research combines different diffusion metrics to enhance the accuracy and sensitivity of lesion detection in MS patients.

type.justification: The study involves the collection and analysis of diffusion MRI data from multiple hospitals, the application of image processing techniques, and statistical analysis to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of diffusion metrics in detecting MS lesions.
type.quote: In this study, we investigate the efficacy of diffusion MRI in distinguishing multiple sclerosis lesions within the cervical spinal cord, using a combination of metrics extracted from diffusion tensor imaging and Ball-and-Stick models.

name.justification: The main focus of the study is on using diffusion MRI, a medical imaging technique, to detect and analyze multiple sclerosis lesions.
name.quote: In this study, we investigate the efficacy of diffusion MRI in distinguishing multiple sclerosis lesions within the cervical spinal cord, using a combination of metrics extracted from diffusion tensor imaging and Ball-and-Stick models.

name.justification: The paper specifically uses metrics extracted from diffusion MRI to assess microstructural changes in tissue and identify MS lesions.
name.quote: Quantitative MRI has the potential to provide valuable intrinsic values of tissue properties that can enhance accuracy. In this study, we investigate the efficacy of diffusion MRI in distinguishing multiple sclerosis lesions within the cervical spinal cord.

name.justification: The study aims to identify and distinguish abnormalities related to multiple sclerosis using diffusion MRI metrics.
name.quote: Our study demonstrates the sensitivity of each metric to underlying microstructure changes in multiple sclerosis patients.

name.justification: The Ball-and-Stick model is used in the study to provide detailed microstructural information about the cervical spinal cord in MS patients.
name.quote: Furthermore, the Ball-and-Stick model has the potential to provide novel information about the microstructure of damaged tissue.

is_contributed.justification: The Ball-and-Stick model is not a novel contribution of this paper but rather an existing model utilized in the study.
is_contributed.quote: The application of these multi-compartment models in the spinal cord requires a high b-value and a high number of diffusion encoding directions, resulting in clinically unfeasible scan times. In addition, although their important findings, the data used is very limited in terms of the number of subjects and the volume of regions in which the diffusion metrics were quantified.

is_executed.justification: The paper involves actual usage of the Ball-and-Stick model to analyze diffusion MRI data.
is_executed.quote: The diffusion-weighted signal in white matter was modeled in the spinal cord using DTI (Basser et al., 1994) and the Ball-and-Stick model (Behrens et al., 2007).

is_compared.justification: The Ball-and-Stick model's performance is compared to other diffusion metrics in the study.
is_compared.quote: Our study demonstrates the sensitivity of each metric to underlying microstructure changes in multiple sclerosis patients. We show that selecting a specific subset of metrics, which provide complementary information, significantly improves the prediction score of lesion presence in the cervical spinal cord.

name.justification: Diffusion Tensor Imaging (DTI) is used as a model in the study to extract various diffusion metrics that are analyzed for detecting MS lesions.
name.quote: In this study, we investigate the efficacy of diffusion MRI in distinguishing multiple sclerosis lesions within the cervical spinal cord, using a combination of metrics extracted from diffusion tensor imaging and Ball-and-Stick models.

is_contributed.justification: Diffusion Tensor Imaging is not a novel contribution of this paper but rather an existing model applied in the study.
is_contributed.quote: Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is a commonly used diffusion MRI technique that can quantify the diffusion of water molecules along different directions and estimate the orientation and integrity of white matter tracts in the CNS.

is_executed.justification: The paper involves actual usage of the DTI model to analyze diffusion MRI data.
is_executed.quote: The diffusion-weighted signal in white matter was modeled in the spinal cord using DTI (Basser et al., 1994) and the Ball-and-Stick model (Behrens et al., 2007).

is_compared.justification: DTI's performance is compared to other diffusion metrics and models in the study.
is_compared.quote: We show that selecting a specific subset of metrics, which provide complementary information, significantly improves the prediction score of lesion presence in the cervical spinal cord.

name.justification: The dataset named EMISEP is used in this study and the approval of the local research ethics committee for this dataset is mentioned.
name.quote: This multicenter study includes 82 participants: 29 healthy volunteers (mean age = 32.83±7.13, 18F/11M) and 53 MS patients (mean age = 32.58±6.25, 34F/19M). All subjects were recruited in accordance with the approval of the local research ethics committee (EMISEP PHRC project 1) and provided informed written consent.
